author: James Whaling
title: Eleven Egyptian ultras sentenced to death after 74 people died in riots at match between Al-Ahly and Al-Masry in 2012
text:
Thank you for subscribing!   
Eleven Egyptian ultras have been sentenced to death following riots in February 2012 which claimed the lives of 74 people. 
Rioting broke out at the end of a fixture between Al-Ahly and Al-Masry in Port Said five years ago leading to one of world football's most deadly stadium disasters. 
The defendants were charged with murder along with other offences with the court upholding the convictions of 22 suspects, receiving up to 10 years behind bars. 
Eleven were sentenced to death but another is still on the run and was tried in his absence. The 2012 riots in Port Said (Photo: Getty) Fans rush on to the pitch (Photo: Getty) A flare is set off during the match (Photo: Getty) 
Cairo's Al-Ahly made the trip to Port Said-based Al-Masry when trouble started at the conclusion of the match. 
Al-Masry fans stormed supporters of their opposition with weapons including knives, rocks and clubs. 
Survivors described fans falling from the stands as they tried to escape the rioting which caused some of the bloodiest scenes seen in football. Fans rioted after the game 74 people were killed Eleven have been sentenced to death (Photo: PA) 
Egypt's top flight was suspended for over a year due to the incident, and when it resumed matches were forced to be played behind closed doors. 
Fans were allowed back into the stadiums three years later, and the first Egyptian Premier League fixture after the ban had been lifted saw 22 fans be killed in a stampede outside the ground. Players escape from the trouble (Photo: AFP) Al-Ahly players flee the scene (Photo: AFP) 
Most of the victims in Port Said belonged to Al-Ahly's 'Ultras Ahlawy' group, which has since been banned by authorities. It was ruled to be a terrorist organisation by an Egyptian court in 2015. 
Earlier this month, over 100 Al-Ahly fans were detained by police over a period of two days on suspicion of planning a protest on the anniversary of the Port Said riots. Like us on Facebook
